title: 112_s1917
content:
The "Middle Class Tax Cut Act of 2011" includes temporary payroll tax relief for employers, employees, and the self-employed. During the payroll tax holiday period, the rate of tax for remuneration received and paid is 3.1 percent under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This applies to employees of qualified employers or those exempt under section 501(a) performing related activities. During the payroll tax holiday period, the rate of self-employment tax under section 1401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is 6.2 percent on net earnings not exceeding $5 million over total remuneration subject to section 3111(a), and 9.3 percent for any additional earnings. During the payroll tax holiday period, the self-employment tax rate is 6.2 percent on net earnings up to $5 million and 9.3 percent on any additional earnings. Deductions for net earnings from self-employment and individual deductions are adjusted accordingly for taxable years during this period. During the payroll tax holiday period in 2012, the self-employment tax rate is 6.2% on net earnings up to $5 million and 9.3% on any additional earnings. The Secretary has regulatory authority to prescribe necessary regulations for this section, including the allocation of excess funds among related taxpayers. The term "payroll tax holiday period" refers to calendar year 2012, and a "qualified employer" is defined accordingly. During the payroll tax holiday period in 2012, the self-employment tax rate is 6.2% on net earnings up to $5 million and 9.3% on any additional earnings. The term "qualified employer" excludes certain entities and includes public institutions of higher education. Aggregation rules similar to sections 414(b), 414(c), 414(m), and 414(o) apply to determine when multiple entities are treated as a single employer. The text discusses transfers of funds to various trust funds and accounts related to Social Security and retirement benefits. The appropriations are made to replicate the transfers that would have occurred if certain amendments had not been enacted. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of an Equivalent Benefit Account under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 to offset revenue reductions from the Railroad Retirement Tax. It also addresses the coordination with other federal laws regarding tax rates. SEC. 102. TEMPORARY TAX CREDIT FOR INCREASED PAYROLL. SEC. 102. TEMPORARY TAX CREDIT FOR INCREASED PAYROLL. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, qualified employers are allowed a payroll increase credit for wages from October 1, 2011, through December 31, 2011, and from January 1, 2012, through December 31, 2012. Qualified employers can receive a payroll increase credit for wages from October 1, 2011, through December 31, 2011, and from January 1, 2012, through December 31, 2012. The credit is calculated based on a percentage of the excess wages from 2012 over 2011, with specific provisions for employers with zero wages in previous years. Qualified employers, excluding certain entities, can receive a payroll increase credit for wages during specific periods. Aggregation rules similar to the Internal Revenue Code apply to determine when multiple entities are treated as a single employer. The Revenue Code of 1986 applies to determine when multiple entities are treated as a single employer for the payroll increase credit. The credit is treated as allowable under the Internal Revenue Code, with limitations on the amount credited against taxes imposed on the employer. Any income tax deduction for amounts paid under the Code is reduced by the credited amounts, and funds are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund. The Social Security Act establishes amounts to offset revenue reductions due to amendments. Funds are transferred from the general fund to replicate Trust Fund transfers. For qualified employers under the Railroad Retirement Taxes, specific sections and terms apply. TITLE II--SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES

SEC. 201. SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to add a new part for a surtax on millionaires. A surtax of 3.25% is imposed on taxpayers with modified adjusted gross income exceeding $1,000,000 ($500,000 for married individuals filing separately) starting after 2012. Dollar amounts are adjusted for inflation annually starting after 2013. The surtax of 3.25% applies to taxpayers with modified adjusted gross income over $1,000,000 ($500,000 for married individuals filing separately) after 2012. Amounts are rounded to the nearest $10,000. Modified adjusted gross income is calculated by deducting investment interest from adjusted gross income. Special rules apply for nonresident aliens and citizens/residents living abroad. The tax imposed under this section shall not be treated as tax imposed by this chapter for purposes of determining the amount of any credit under this chapter or for purposes of section 55. The amendment on surtax for millionaires is not considered a change in tax rate under the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012.
